user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_virt2phys:
```c
static int metal_virt2phys(void *addr, unsigned long *phys)
{
	off_t offset;
	uint64_t entry;
	int error;

	if (_metal.pagemap_fd < 0)
		return -EINVAL;

	offset = ((uintptr_t)addr >> _metal.page_shift) * sizeof(entry);
	error = pread(_metal.pagemap_fd, &entry, sizeof(entry), offset);
	if (error < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed pagemap pread (offset %llx) - %s\n",
			  (unsigned long long)offset, strerror(errno));
		return -errno;
	}

	/* Check page present and not swapped. */
	if ((entry >> 62) != 2) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "pagemap page not present, %llx -> %llx\n",
			  (unsigned long long)offset, (unsigned long long)entry);
		return -ENOENT;
	}

	*phys = (entry & ((1ULL << 54) - 1)) << _metal.page_shift;
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_virt2phys:
extern struct metal_state _metal
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I selected fragments that can cause control-flow exits or depend on bit/shift operations and macro expansion — these are the places where unreachable code can appear (early returns, branches that may be optimized away, or macro-expanded constructs that may compile to nothing). I did NOT include the remaining simple declarations (off_t offset; uint64_t entry; int error;), the function signature, or small syntactic glue (braces, blank lines, comments) because they are not control-flow constructs that could be statically unreachable. I also omitted internal uses of standard library calls (strerror, pread prototype) themselves as separate fragments because they are used only within the branches already listed; investigating the listed branches covers their relevance to reachability. The selected fragments cover: the initial guard and its return, the offset computation (shifts that could be out-of-range), the pread error branch and its return, the pagemap-present check and its return, the final assignment/return, and the metal_log macro definition (macro expansion can render statements effectively absent/unreachable). These are the code locations that should be inspected to determine whether any code paths are actually unreachable under the build/configuration in scope.
